header.title: The Samhain Song Press Ultimate Grimoire and Spellbook Of Real Ancient Witchcraft

central_thesis: This compilation presents 'un-fluffy' ancient witchcraft practices, spells, incantations, herbal lore, and cures from diverse historical sources (all pre-1900). It aims to offer practical, operative magic, distinguishing these historical methods from modern, sanitized versions of Wicca, while also cautioning contemporary practitioners on adapting potentially 'grotesque' or harmful methods.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part One: Charms, Spells and Cures as Recorded In Ancient Legends, Mystic Charms, and Superstitions of Ireland
structure_content.summary: This section delves into Irish folk magic, presenting a wide array of spells and superstitions related to love (including highly unethical methods like using corpse skin), curses, healing remedies, and divinations tied to seasonal festivals (May Day, Midsummer, November Eve, Whitsuntide). It details practices involving animals (cats, dogs, birds) and plants, emphasizing the role of 'fairy doctors' and the potent, often fatal, power of poetic maledictions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Two: Blessings, Curses, Spells and Strange Magicks From ARADIA or the Gospel of the Witches
structure_content.summary: Focusing on an Italian witchcraft tradition, this part describes invocations to Diana and her daughter Aradia for protection, success (e.g., finding hidden treasures, ensuring a good vintage), and compelling love, alongside powerful curses against oppressors. Rituals often involve specific ingredients (meal, salt, honey, wine), the use of enchanted objects (lemons with pins, round stones), and practices such as naked gatherings and feasting under the guidance of Diana.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Three: Incantations and Specimens of Medical Magic From GYPSY SORCERY and FORTUNE TELLING
structure_content.summary: This segment outlines Transylvanian Gypsy magical practices primarily for healing various ailments like fevers, boils, headaches, and barrenness, as well as for protecting domestic animals and recovering stolen property. Methods incorporate herbal remedies, specific chants and incantations (often in Romani), and sympathetic magic, frequently utilizing animal parts, blood, and ritual locations like cross-roads or running streams. It also explores love charms and fortune-telling techniques.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Four: A Collection Of Mysterious And Invaluable Arts And Remedies, For Man As Well As Animals, With Many Proofs From JOHN GEORGE HOHMAN’S POW-WOWS; OR, LONG LOST FRIEND
structure_content.summary: A compendium of Pennsylvania Dutch folk magic, offering practical remedies for human and animal health issues (e.g., hysterics, bleeding, worms, poll-evil in horses). It details charms against injuries, thieves, and witchcraft, and provides instructions for making divinatory wands and protective talismans. Many practices involve specific verbal formulas, often with Christian invocations, and precise material components or actions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part Five: THE FOLK-LORE OF PLANTS by T.F. Thiselton-Dyer
structure_content.summary: This extensive section provides a scholarly exploration of the historical, mythical, and superstitious associations of plants across diverse cultures. It covers plant-life concepts, plant worship, connections to lightning, roles in witchcraft and demonology, fairy-lore, love-charms, dream-plants, weather prognostication, proverbs, ceremonial use, plant names, and their legendary history. While rich in cultural context for plant magic, it is descriptive rather than offering operative spells.

key_concepts.definition: A form of ancient, real witchcraft described as a supernatural path to personal power, often morally-neutral or violent, contrasting sharply with modern, 'fluffy bunny' Wicca.
A malign influence believed to cause harm, illness, or misfortune. Cures often involve specific charms, spitting, or transferring the 'evil' to other objects or spirits.

The influence exerted by a spirit-race (Sidhe, Peris, Feadh-Ree), capable of both good and evil, with specific requirements, taboos, and interactions with mortals. Their actions can range from bestowing luck to inflicting curses or abducting people.
An old medical theory asserting that the external characteristics of a plant (e.g., color, shape, growth habit) visually indicate the specific diseases or body parts it is intended to remedy.

A tool, typically a forked hazel wand, used for locating hidden substances like water, ore, or treasure, and sometimes for detecting thieves or foretelling events, often activated by specific rituals and invocations.

Ancient pagan fires, primarily associated with sun-worship and purification, lit during festivals like May Eve and Midsummer. These traditions later syncretized with Christian feast days, retaining their magical significance for fertility, protection, and divination.

The inherent magical efficacy of spoken words, incantations, blessings, and curses, believed to manifest reality, influence events, and cause physical or spiritual effects. This power is often enhanced by specific divine or infernal invocations.

practical_system.description: The practical system presented across these texts is a diverse amalgamation of folk magical traditions, emphasizing sympathetic magic, invocation, and the ritualistic use of natural elements. It operates on principles of sympathetic correspondence, the power of the spoken word, and the manipulation of 'spirits' (fairies, demons, or divine entities). Rituals are often specific to ailments, desires, or protections, and frequently incorporate elements of Christian piety alongside older pagan beliefs. The effectiveness of a charm often relies on precise timing (moon phases, specific days), secrecy, the practitioner's faith, and the proper collection and preparation of materials.
tools: Animal parts (frog organs, black cat liver/blood/hairs, wolf's eye, vulture knee stone, horse's back tooth)
Specific plants and herbs (yarrow, mint, hemlock, vervain, rue, foxglove, marsh marigold, elder, dandelion, oak bark, tobacco, chic-weed, apple, pear, clover)
Everyday objects (salt, water, meal, honey, wine, candles, knives, pins, thread, rags, paper, eggs, milk, whiskey, vinegar, animal dung)
Sacred objects (holy stones, crystals, crosses, relics like coffin nails or criminal's skull scrapings)
Ritual locations (churchyards, cross-roads, running streams, fairy raths, specific trees, stable thresholds)
rituals: Corpse Skin Love Charm: Obtaining a strip of skin from a newly-buried corpse and tying it around a sleeping target after an invocation to the devil to compel love.
Diana's Sabbat: Participating in nude witch-meetings with feasting, dancing, music, and love-making in darkness, where Diana extinguishes the lights and grants desires.
Lemon and Pins Spell: Sticking pins (of various colors for luck, black for malice) into a lemon with invocations to Diana to influence fortune or bring harm to an enemy.

Thief Spell-binding: Using powerful Christian invocations (e.g., 'Oh, Peter, oh Peter, borrow the power from God...') to physically bind thieves in place, often by speaking toward them and making crosses.
Fever Cures: Diverse methods including consuming powdered frog organs in spirits, shaking a young tree at sunrise with chants, or throwing salt into a stream while reciting a charm.
Divining for a Spouse: Various techniques such as placing a snail on a flour plate overnight to reveal an initial, or performing rituals with an apple under the pillow on specific nights.
Cattle Protection Charms: Driving cattle through fires, sprinkling blood on fodder, or burying bundles of specific herbs and dirt near thresholds to ward off theft, illness, and witchcraft.
Healing Wounds/Ailments: Applying specific herbal plasters and decoctions (e.g., iron-weed for ulcers, white lily for sores) often combined with crosses or invocations to saints.

These Witches generally view religious Wicca as a naïve modern creation, a 'fluffy bunny' social movement closely akin to the crystal-waving New Age groups that have flourished throughout America and Europe since the 1930s.
When you read these passages, see past the veneer to the truths contained inside. Change 'Jesus' to 'Zeus' or 'Thor' and 'The Virgin Mary' to 'Hera' or 'Freya,' and the spell will still work.

Finally, please be aware that much real ancient witchcraft was, to put it frankly, quite grotesque. Some spells in this volume call for the flesh of human corpses or the body parts of animals. Any 21st century magick user worth his or her salt, and with a copy of any 'Wicca-101' table of correspondences in hand, ought to be able to dream up a dozen non-lethal, safe and legal substitutions for any such spell ingredient.
A POTENT love-charm used by women is a piece of skin taken from the arm of a corpse and tied on the person while sleeping whose love is sought.

When a girl wishes to gain the love of a man, and to make him marry her, the dreadful spell is used called Drimial Agus Thorial. At dead of night, she and an accomplice go to a churchyard, exhume a newly-buried corpse, and take a strip of the skin from the head to the heel. This is wound round the girl as a belt with a solemn invocation to the devil for his help.

Who art indeed our body, since without thee We could not live, thou who (at first as seed) Before becoming flower went in the earth, Where all deep secrets hide, and then when ground Didst dance like, dust in the wind, and yet meanwhile Didst bear with thee in flitting, secrets strange!

When a man has been 'struck by a spirit' there results a sore swelling or boil, which is cured by a sorceress as follows: The patient is put into a tent by himself, and is given divers drinks by his attendant then she rubs the sufferer with a salve, the secret of which is known only to her, while she chants:-- 'Prejiá, prejiá, prejiá, Kiyá miseçeske, ác odoy; Trianda sapa the çaven tut, Trianda jiuklá tut čingeren, Trianda káçná tut čunáven!' 'Begone, begone, begone To the Evil One; stay there. May thirty snakes devour thee, Thirty dogs tear thee, Thirty cocks swallow thee!'

Take a piece of old bacon, and cut it into small pieces, put them in a pan and roast them well, put in a handful of fish-worms, a gill of oats and three spoonfuls of salt into it; roast the whole of this until it turns black, and then filter it through a cloth; after which you put a gill of soft soap, half a gill of rye whiskey, half a gill of vinegar, and half a pint of rain-water to it; mix it well, and smear it over the part affected with sweeney on the third, the sixth, and the ninth day of the new moon, and warm it with an oaken board.

The old medical theory, which supposed that plants by their external character indicated the particular diseases for which Nature had intended them as remedies, was simply a development of the much older notion of a real connection between object and image.

critical_analysis.relevance: This compilation offers profound insight into historical folk magic and grimoire traditions preceding modern Wicca. It highlights the pervasive syncretism of Christian and pagan elements in operative magic across different cultures (Irish, Italian, Gypsy, Pennsylvania Dutch) and provides a valuable resource for understanding the practical applications and underlying beliefs of these systems, often revealing their raw, unfiltered nature.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is academic researchers and serious practitioners of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Folk Magic. It also appeals to historians of religion, cultural anthropologists, and those interested in the historical evolution and practical mechanics of 'un-fluffy' magical traditions, with a clear warning regarding the ethical and legal implications of some described practices.
